$! You may need to tell DVLA if you've had an intracerebral haemorrhage. $!

% You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted. %

##Car or motorcycle licence

You only need to tell DVLA if you're still having problems a month after an intracerebral haemorrhage. If you are, fill in form STR1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

$D [Download ‘STR1 - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 298KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_178631.pdf "Download medical questionnaire"){:rel="external"} $D

Download information leaflet 'TIA1' for more information on driving after a stroke or transient ischaemic attack. 

$D
[Download form 'TIA1 - Car or motorcycle drivers who have had a stroke or transient ischaemic attack' (PDF, 260KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_067958.pdf  "Download 'Form TIA1' (PDF, 260KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Bus, coach or lorry licence

You'll must tell DVLA. Fill in form STR1V and send to the address on the form.

$D [Download ‘STR1V - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 315KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_201618.pdf "Download medical questionnaire"){:rel="external"} $D
overview: You may need to tell DVLA if you've had an intracerebral haemorrhage - if you do, download the correct form to let them know
title: Intracerebral haemorrhage and driving
